meanings.def: to come together, or bring people together, in one place to form a group
examples: A crowd soon gathered.
+ adv./prep. His supporters gathered in the main square.
Can you all gather round? I've got something to tell you.
The whole family gathered together at Ray's home.
be gathered + adv./prep. They were all gathered round the TV.
A large crowd was gathered outside the studio.
The kids were gathered together in one room.
They are all gathering for a major conference.
The boys gathered around the car.

meanings.def: to bring things together that have been spread around
examples: gather something People slowly gathered their belongings and left the hall.
I waited while he gathered up his papers.
gather something together She gathered her things together and got to her feet.
We’ve been collecting data from various sources.
Dirt had collected in the corners of the room.
I waited while he gathered up his papers.
Detectives have spent months gathering evidence.
I seem to have accumulated a lot of books.
Debts began to accumulate.
He amassed a fortune from silver mining.

meanings.def: to collect information from different sources
examples: to gather information/data/intelligence
Detectives have spent months gathering evidence.
We’ve been collecting data from various sources.
Dirt had collected in the corners of the room.
I waited while he gathered up his papers.
Detectives have spent months gathering evidence.
I seem to have accumulated a lot of books.
Debts began to accumulate.
He amassed a fortune from silver mining.

meanings.def: to collect plants, fruit, etc. from a wide area
examples: to gather wild flowers
They lived in the forest, gathering mushrooms and berries to eat.

meanings.def: to pick or cut and collect crops to be stored
examples: It was late August and the harvest had been safely gathered in.

meanings.def: to believe or understand that something is true because of information or evidence you have
examples: gather (that)… I gather (that) you wanted to see me.
I gather from your letter that you're not enjoying your job.
gather (something) ‘There's been a delay.’ ‘I gathered that.’
‘She won't be coming.’ ‘So I gather.’
You're self-employed, I gather.
As far as I can gather, he got involved in a fight.
From what I can gather, there's been some kind of problem.

meanings.def: to increase in speed, force, etc.
examples: The truck gathered speed.
During the 1980s the green movement gathered momentum.
Thousands of these machines are gathering dust (= not being used) in stockrooms.
As the weeks passed, Charlotte began to gather strength.

meanings.def: to gradually increase in number or amount
examples: The storm clouds were gathering.
the gathering gloom of a winter’s afternoon

meanings.def: to pull a piece of clothing tighter to your body
examples: gather something around you/something He gathered his cloak around him.
gather something up She gathered up her skirts and ran.

meanings.def: to pull parts of a piece of clothing together in folds and sew them in place
examples: She wore a skirt gathered (in) at the waist.

meanings.def: to pull somebody towards you and put your arms around them
examples: She gathered the child in her arms and held him close.
He gathered her to him.
He gathered her close and kissed her.

meanings.def: to prepare yourself to do something that requires effort
examples: I sat down for a moment to gather my strength.
She was still trying to gather her thoughts together when the door opened.
Fortunately the short delay gave him time to gather himself.

meanings.def: to get your breath back after an effort
examples: He paused to gather his breath.

meanings.def: to not be used for a long time
examples: Play your guitar that's gathering dust, or pull out the old tennis racket for a match.
You may already have an old laptop that is collecting dust but otherwise usable.

meanings.def: a person who moves from place to place, job to job, etc. does not have a lot of money, possessions or friends but is free from responsibilities
